creator: umagesh@rediffmail.com
text:
JDK's Jar task recognizes lines which contain just white spaces as 'empty 
lines'. Ant's Manifest.java's interpretation of an empty line is not
consistent with that of Sun's JDK.  I have provided a patch at:

http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=ant-dev&m=100283161417003&w=2

Strictly speaking such a line is a continuation line according to the BNF in the
jar file spec. But that spec is now pretty much discredited :-( Oh well.
creator: conor@apache.org
umagesh@apache.org
text: OK.  I will revert this.  I agree we shold adhere to specs as much as possible.

creator: conor@apache.org
text:
No, don't roll it back. I think the patch is a good idea. In the end, we must be
somewhat practical. As I said the spec has many holes and people will expect the
behaviour of jar to set the standard, not the spec. So, IMHO, patch should stay.

creator: umagesh@apache.org
text:
It seems like the spaces get appended to the attribute's value, which means
that the first character being a space, marks line continuation and the 
line contains nothing but spaces.  Anyways, here is a manifest that will be
accepted by JDK's jar and not by Ant's.
<Snip>
Name: x.jar
 
                        
attribute: xy.jar

</snip>
(I hope bugzilla doesn't trim the spaces.)
It is real low priority.  I will leave it to you, Conor, to decide on what's 
best.
